Summary: Posing questions to councilor candidates and posting their repsonses on Facebook

Title: Dawson Creek Drag Race 2020
Summary: Welcome to Dawson Creek Pride's first Drag Competition! Due to COVID 19, this year Dawson Creek Pride's Drag and Costume Competition will be held online. Enter your fierce looks or performances for a chance to win fun prizes!

Title: Dawson Creek Pride Film Event 2020
Dawson Creek Pride Festival Dates 2021
Dawson Creek Pride Guide 2021
Summary: Hello DC LGBTQ+ Community! We at DCPS have decided to post-pone our usual dance/festivities for this year. In light of the pandemic, we would like to wait until we can hold an in person event that will be safe for all, have great attendance, and be an event our community can take great pride in. Instead, we've decided to organize some fun events over Zoom and Teleparty, so we can still connect as a Queer community during this spooky month.

Title: Dawson Creek Pride Walk 2022
Summary: Join us for a wonderful Pride Walk, celebrating June Pride 2022! Dress up in your finest rainbow attire and walk to show your support of the LGBTQ2S+ community.

Title: Dawson Creek Pride Society Bowling Celebration 2022
Summary:
June 25th 7-9pm at Hypertension Escape Bowling.
A Pride Bowling Celebration is go!
If you RSVP’d a yes on our posts, please be sure to arrive at 7pm for the fun!

Title: Dawson Creek Pride Guide 2022
Summary:
YOU BETTA WERK, WITCH!
Dawson Creek's 15th Annual Pride Celebration
Friday October 28th, 2022 at KPAC, 7pm - 12 am
Drag show at 8 pm, dance to follow. This event is for Ages 14+. (Note: Based on calculations, it seems 2020 and 2021 annual events were not regarded as annual Pride celebrations because of Covid.)

Summary: 2pm, Java World,

Title: Cowichan Pride July Potluck Picnic 2014
Summary:
1pm, Centennial Stairs, Our inaugural potluck is going to be awesome! To identify the group, a few of us will be bringing vases of flowers, like hydrangeas and daisies. It'd be so pretty!
We plan to be at the picnic shelter so even if it rains, it should be OK so long as another group doesn't get there first.

Title: Cowichan Pride August Coffee Meet 2014
Summary: 2pm, Java World,

Title: Cowichan Pride August Hike & Picnic 2014
Summary:
11am, Mt. Prevost, Meet at Java World parking lot to car pool at 11am.
This is a short hike I've heard.  Part of the road is gravel so if you have low clearance on your car, you might want to carpool with somebody who does. Bring your own snacks and drinks. Bring a cameraphone so you can take a photo through Roger's telescope. All are welcome. So bring friends, neighbours, relatives, family, etc.

Title: Cowichan Pride September Coffee Meet 2014
Summary: 2pm, Java World

Summary: 2pm, Java World, Meet other people in the LGBTQ community and their supporters. Hear what's happening in the community. Help plan social events.

Summary: 2pm, Java World, Meet other people in the LGBTQ community and their supporters. Hear what's happening in the community. Help plan social events.

Summary: 2pm, Java World, Meet other people in the LGBTQ community and their supporters. Hear what's happening in the community. Help plan social events.

Title: Cowichan Pride Potluck & Games Night 2015
Summary: 5:30pm, near Sherman Rd. & Somenos Rd, Potluck, Games and Conversation!

Title: Cowichan Pride Karaoke at The Courts 2015
Summary: 10pm, You don't have to sing but you can try getting your friends to sing! Look out for Jim and Roger who will be wearing bandannas (probably tie-dye rainbow ones).

Title: Cowichan Pride Film night in Maple Bay 2015
Summary:
6-9pm, 6610 Pemberlea Rd, Screening of "Pride (2014)"
We'll provide popcorn, coffee & tea. Not necessary, but you're welcome to bring snacks. If people want an intermission halfway through, to mingle, have a bathroom break, snack, get more popcorn, we can do that.

Title: Cowichan Pride April Social 2015
Summary: 7pm, TBA (no longer bowling... maybe a pub? what else is there to do in Duncan?)

Title: Cowichan Pride Pub Gathering 2015
Summary: 6pm, Craig Street Brew Pub, Come one come all for some LGBTQIA tribe time.

Title: Cowichan Pride BBQ Potluck 2015
Summary:
6pm, 441 Goulet Road Mill Bay, Hello all your super rad LGBTQIA folks of the Cowichan Valley! The heat is on, and summer is officially here. Come chill and connect with your local tribe for a BBQ potluck at an oasis by the sea ❤ I will provide hamburgers, buns, condiments and a bottle of wine for those who are interested. Please bring your own beer/drinks and post what you can bring below. Look forward to seeing you there! ❤ Big love
Ps. Please note this event is Transexual, Faerie and faggot inclusive.. We welcome all colors of the rainbow

Title: Cowichan Pride Bowling 2015
Summary: 8pm, Duncan Lanes bowling Alley, Hey LGBTQIA tribe of the Cowichan Valley! Lets come together and reconnect for bowling! Big love, and looking forward to connecting with you soon! This event is welcoming of all colors of the rainbow.

Title: Cowichan Pride Potluck 2016
Summary: 6pm, 6610 Pemberlea Rd, Potluck & planning meeting for a Cowichan Pride entry in the inaugural Nanaimo Pride Parade on Sunday June 12.

Title: Cowichan Pride Entry in Nanaimo Pride Parade 2016
Summary: 11am, 13 Commercial Street, Cowichan Pride is marching in Nanaimo's first Pride Parade. Entry #21: Meet in front of "Catwalk Fashions" store, 13 Commercial Dr. Everybody welcome, especially allies!

Title: Cowichan Pride Raising the Pride Flag 2016
Summary: 3:30-4:00pm, City Hall, Duncan deputy mayor, John Horgan, will be raising the Pride flag to half-mast for the victims in Orlando.

Title: Cowichan Pride Entry in Victoria Pride Parade 2016
Summary: 12-1pm, Macdonald Park, Cowichan Pride is now registered to march in the Victoria Pride Parade on Sunday, July 10. Hope you and your friends and families can join us to show that the Cowichan Valley is a progessive place in which to live.

Title: Cowichan Pride Picnic 2016
Summary: 1-4pm, Kinsol Trestle, Friends, families and allies are also welcome. Rain or shine. There is a covered picnic area.

Title: Cowichan Pride Entry in Nanaimo Pride Parade 2017
Summary: 11-2pm, Cowichan Pride is marching in Nanaimo's second Pride Parade. Entry #1 is recognizing the first anniversary of the Orlando Pulse Nightclub shooting. We are entry #2 with Warmland Women's Support Services behind us as #3. Everybody welcome, especially allies!

Title: Cowichan Pride Entry in Victoria Pride Parade 2017
Summary: 11-3pm, McPherson Playhouse, Hope you and your friends and families can join us to show that the Cowichan Valley is a progessive place in which to live.

Title: Cowichan Pride Entry in Duncan Day Parade 2017
Summary: 11-1pm, Please walk with us in the parade. We're entry #28. Cowichan Pride & Warmland Women's Support Services are marching together side by side in the Duncan Day Grande Parade. Thanks for their sponsorship. This is Duncan's chance to show there is support for a rainbow crosswalk and a Cowichan Pride Society. Everybody welcome, especially allies!

Title: Cowichan Pride Raising the Pride Flag 2019
Summary: 3:30-4:00pm, City Hall, The pride flag will be raised for the week at Duncan City Hall, to commemorate the 50th anniversary of May 14, 1969, the decriminalization of homosexuality in the bedrooms of the nation. Let's learn about history, celebrate progress made so far, and continue that progress toward equality and equity.

Title: Cowichan Pride Entry in Nanaimo Pride Parade 2019
Summary: 12-1:15pm, Cowichan Pride is marching in Nanaimo's fourth Pride Parade. Everybody welcome, especially allies!

Title: Cowichan Pride Entry in Victoria Pride Parade 2019
Summary: 11-12pm, Victoria will be having their annual Pride parade and festival on Sunday, July 7th. Cowichan Pride will be marching in the parade, and we'd love for you to join us!  Please feel free to invite anyone you think would like to walk with our group and celebrate Pride.

Title: Cowichan Pride Entry in Panago Parade 2019
Summary: It's the last parade of the summer season for Cowichan Pride! Join us in our hometown, Duncan BC, for the Panago Parade on Saturday, July 13th. Parade starts at 10:00AM. We warmly welcome anyone who would like to walk with us and represent the LGBTQ2S+ community here in the valley (allies included!). **Important** The theme for this parade is "Christmas in July".

Title: Burnaby Intercultural Table The Community Forum 2018
Summary: The Burnaby Intercultural Table hosted a community forum to better understand the challenges of 2SLGBTQIA+ newcomers and to provide educational opportunities for frontline workers on issues addressing the 2SLGBTQIA+ community. From this initial conversation, the Burnaby Pride Planning Committee was formed.

Title: Burnaby Intercultural Table The Inaugural Event 2018
Summary: The event aimed to launch a lasting movement that would honour, celebrate, and educate about 2SLGBTQIA+ folk in Burnaby.

Title: Burnaby Raise the Flags 2019
Summary: Burnaby Pride joined Mayor Hurley, members of Burnaby City Council, and City of Burnaby staff to raise the Pride flag for the 2nd year, and the trans flag for the first time ever at Burnaby City Hall.

Title: Burnaby Pride The Rainbow Garden Party 2019
Summary: The Rainbow Garden Party was held at Burnaby Civic Square, next to Metrotown Library and was more adult-oriented, including drag performers, a DJ, candy, ice cream, food trucks, drinks, and dancing. It was a wonderful celebration with a great crowd and energizing vibe.

Title: Burnaby Pride The Pride Street Festival 2019
Summary: The Pride Street Festival was held on Jubilee Avenue and brought together service providers and entertainment. To celebrate the diversity of the LGBTQ2S+ community in Burnaby with an afternoon of live performances, food, art, games, and community resources.

Title: Burnaby Pride Disability Awareness Workshop
Summary: 1-3 pm, Online, with Heather McCain, a disabled, queer, trans advocate and educator. In this session to understand what disability is, the types of disability, the current language of disability, what ableism is, and how you can actively fight against it.

Title: Burnaby Pride Digital Celebration 2021
Summary: 7-9pm, Online, LGBTQ+ Book Talks with Dr. Rob Bittner, LGBTQ+ Children's and Young Adult Lit Specialist.  The Performance: jaibrend RainbowGlitz, missmondayblues, mandastroyer, anjalicrush, Parlour Panthe, Stephen and more.

Title: Burnaby Pride Hiring A Coordinator
Summary: Coordinator. Fixed-term position, 35 hours per week, meets Canada jobs criteria (under 30 years old). Deadline May 6. Send your CV.

Title: Burnaby Pride BBQ In The Park 2022
Summary: 2-6pm, Lobley Park, This is a free event and we encourage families and individuals alike to join us, there will be music, food and fun. There’ll be a selection of hot dogs (meat/veggie/Halal), pop and chips on offer. We’ll have music from Kaya a Burnaby-based vocalist and songwriter.

Title: Burnaby Pride Pre-Pride Celebrations 2022
Summary: 7pm, Studio Brewing, The amazing @kayakurz will be performing 5pm-7pm, and the equally fabulous @itsfairything will be on at 8pm-10pm. @birriayvr Food Truck will be there to keep the hunger at bay.

Title: Burnaby Pride Celebrations 2022
Summary: 12-6pm, Civic Square, Burnaby’s Pride event celebrates the diversity of our local 2SLGBTQIA+ (Two-Spirit, Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Transgender, Queer, Intersex, Asexual/Aromantic, Plus) community and all those who support them. Be back with in-person programming for 2022. Returning to Civic Square (home of Burnaby Pride’s 2019 Garden Party) The event feature a variety of live music, drag, comedy and more, along with educational booths and activities for the whole family.

Title: First Taber Pride Hosted by Taber Equality Alliance Society
Summary: Taber Equality Alliance Society hosted Taber's first Pride event on June 12, 2017 at Confederation Park from 4-9 p.m. called Pride in the Park. The event featured the raising of the Pride flag at 6 p.m. and speeches. Following that, there were music and performances at Cornfest Stage. Food and non-alcoholic beverages were available at this all inclusive family friendly event.

Title: Taber Equality Alliance Society raises Pride flag Three times in response to vandalism 2017
Summary: 2017 Pride: The Pride flag had to be raised three times at Confederation Park during the month of June. It was first raised on June 12 during Taber's first Pride event; however, it was stolen and found shredded on June 19th. A second flag was raised but was found burned on the flagpole on June 25th. On June 26th, Taber Equality Alliance Society raised a third Pride flag, which was donated by Lethbridge Pride.

Title: Pride Flag Raising Request Denied by Taber Town Council 2018
Summary: In January of 2018, Taber Equality Alliance Society submitted an application to Taber's Town Council to fly the Pride flag on the community flagpole at Confederation Park, where the Pride flag was flown and twice vandalized during the previous Pride celebration in June 2017. Taber Town Council voted against flying the Pride flag on the community flagpole in Confederate Park and passed a motion stipulating that no flags other than the Alberta, Canada or Taber flags could be flown from the flag pole. Shannon Phillips and Sandra Jansen, Members of the Alberta Legislative Assembly, stepped in and granted permission for the Pride flag to be flown at the Taber Provincial Building.

Title: Taber Pride 2018
Summary: On June 2, 2018, Taber Equality Alliance Society and Taber Pride hosted Taber's 2nd annual Pride in the Park celebration. The event featured a flag raising ceremony from 1-2 p.m. in front of the Provincial Building at 5011 49 Avenue and entertainment from 2-8 p.m. at Confederation Park. There was a bouncy castle, face painting, food and beer gardens. At 10 p.m., there was a Taber Pride After Party hosted by the Heritage Inn at Tank 77.

Organization Name: ["Taber Equality Alliance Society","Taber Public Library","Taber Pride"]

Title: Taber Pride: Government Involvement 2019
Summary: Town councillors Carly Firth and Jack Brewin attended the flag raising. Among other dignitaries were fire chief Steve Munshaw and police chief Graham Abela, along with David Khan, leader of the Alberta Liberal Party. Official opposition leader Rachel Notley also gave a recorded message of well wishes. Devon Hargreaves, 2019 Alberta Liberal Party candidate in Lethbridge-East, was also in attendance.

Title: Taber Pride: Government and Corporate Support 2019
Summary: In 2019, the Town of Taber advertised the Pride event on their digital sign and lent a hand with some labour, helping set up the barriers for the beer gardens. According to a member of the Taber Equality Alliance, the Heritage Inn advertised the event on their digital sign as well, without any prompting by the group. Talking about corporate support, the Oilmen’s Club ran a Pride Trivia the night before Pride and committed to sponsoring the beer gardens this year and in the future.

Title: Taber Pride 2020
Summary: Taber Pride, Laura Ross-Giroux and Amy Tiberghien Hall held Pride online due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Pride ran from June 2, 2020 to June 20, 2020. Online events included watching a livestream of the flag raising ceremony at Taber Provincial Building and live performances. The flag-raising event occurred on June 6, 2020 at 3 p.m. Taber Equality Alliance Society also issued a call for submissions from the public for artwork, poetry, writing and videos showing people's Pride, which they posted on their Facebook and Instagram pages during Pride. Taber Pride also played a three-part Telus original documentary series called "Small Town Queer" filmed in Alberta on its Facebook page during Pride month.

Title: Taber Pride 2022
Summary: 2022 Pride: Taber Pride resumed in-person Pride celebrations in 2022 and held events on June 3 and June 4. On June 3, 2022, Taber Pride hosted a 'Queer 101' presentation at the Taber Public Library at 7 p.m. in association with OUTreach Southern Alberta. On June 4, 2022, the Pride celebration began with a Drag Queen Story Time featuring Francheska Dynamites at Taber Public Library at 11:30 a.m. At 12:30 p.m., the Pride flag was raised at Taber Provincial Building. From 1:30 p.m. to 7 p.m., festivities continued in Confederation Park, where attendees enjoyed live music, face painting, a bouncy house, and food trucks. There was also a performance by drag queen Francheska Dynamites.

Title: First Okotoks Pride Hosted By Foothills Rainbow Connection
Summary: Foothills Rainbow Connection hosted pride events on a smaller scale in 2017 – which were the first pride events to hit Okotoks. After a one year hiatus Pride was set to return, but was cancelled due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

Title: Foothills Rainbow Connection Founder
Summary: Marissa Angel Johnston founded the Foothills Rainbow Connection in 2017. Foothills Rainbow Connection is a grassroots initiative that strives to empower the local LGBTQ community and its allies through increased visibility and awareness.

Title: 'Pride in the Park' Hosted by Foothills Rainbow Connection hosts 2017
Summary:
June 2017: The Foothills Rainbow Connection hosted a pride gathering in 2017 called 'Pride in the Park.' This event consisted of Drag performances, music, story times for young children surrounding tales of inclusion and diversity and numerous vendors. They also flew a giant rainbow flag at Ethel Tucker Park on August 26.
This was the first event for the community and was largely requested by the public to increase visiblity for the local LGBTQ community.

Title: Okotoks Pride hosts first 'Together with Pride Street Festival' 2022
Summary:
First-ever 'Together with Pride Street Festival' held on Saturday June 4, 2022. The festival was kicked off with Okotoks' rainbow crosswalk receiving a fresh coat of rainbow paint at 12 p.m.
The festival featured an open mic, welcoming anyone who wished to perform.
In the evening, the festival concluded with a full drag show produced by Tom Barker, co-chair of Okotoks Pride, and showcased fellow Okotoks Pride co-chair Shannon MacPherson, also known as drag king Shane Onyou.

Summary: Announced on Facebook and Instagram on December 4, 2022, Okotoks Pride Society has become incorporated

Title: Okotoks Pride Month 2023
Summary: June 2023: Okotoks Pride Society opened Pride Month on June 1, 2023 with the launch of a year-long social media contest called the "#MakingOkotoksProud" on Facebook and Instagram. "To keep the importance of Pride at our forefront for the 53 weeks until we do it all again, we are launching a year long photo contest: #MakingOkotoksProud! Use this hashtag and tag us when you see and share, on Facebook or Instagram, any happenings and random rainbow finds that bring Pride to Okotoks and make you Proud of Okotoks. We realize that this hopefully won’t just bring Pride-related thoughts to mind, and that’s totally cool! This is a diverse Community in a vibrant Town with lots to do. So, go do the things and tag us! {Winner(s?) will get a Pride Kit to help them kick off the season next year, and will be chosen by random draw. Photos tagged will likely be shared in our stories and we won’t be able to count entries from private posts.}"

Title: First Okotoks Pride Week
Summary: Okotoks' first-ever Pride Week was held from June 4-11, 2023. Okotoks Pride Society and Okotoks Town Council kicked the week off on June 4 with a Pride Proclamation and the raising of a new Philly Pride Flag at the Okotoks Municipal Centre. On June 10, the Okotoks Pride Society closed Pride Week by hosting a Pride Party Open Stage Show at Salutè cocktail bar in Okotoks, which featured drag and burlesque shows headlined by local and non-local performers and community members.

Title: Okotoks Pride Locations 2023
Summary: Okotoks Town Council (Pride Proclamation and Flag Raising on June 4, 2023), McRae Street (Youth Celebration Expo on June 4, 2023) & Salutè cocktail bar (Pride Party Open Stage Show on June 10, 2023)

Title: Okotoks Pride Headliners 2023
Summary: Headliners for the Pride Party Open Stage Show: Birthday Girl, Shane Onyou, Imogen Rouge, Mr. Justin Syde and QT Pie

Title: Youth Celebration Expo 2023
Summary: Following the Pride flag raising event on June 4, the True Colors Rainbow Alliance hosted the first-ever Youth Celebration Expo at the Landmark Site on McRae Street. Its family-friendly activities included potato sack and three-legged races, face painting, balloons and market vendors.

Title: Pride Week receives official proclamation from municipality 2023
Summary: Government Involvement: Members of Okotoks Town Council proclaimed June 4 - 11, 2023 as “PRIDE WEEK” in the Town of Okotoks on May 23, 2023.

Title: Medicine Hat Pride Association changes name to Sun City Pride Association
Summary: Medicine Hat Pride Association decided to change its name to Sun City Pride Association in September 2018. This was done as part of efforts to rebuild the organization and re-brand as a year-round resource and support system for the community rather than as an organization that hosts pride celebrations in Medicine Hat for one week or one month every year.

Title: Sun City Pride Association Logo
Summary: Sun City Pride Association's logo

Title: Project Rainbow Medicine Hat is founded
Summary:
We are an independent group of activists and advocates dedicated to serving the unique needs of Medicine Hat's LGBTQ2S+ community through direct action, outreach and boots-to-the-ground activism. Our focus is awareness, community support, and intersectional inclusion of ALL the beautiful facets of our LGBTQ2S+ community.
We aim to provide support and outreach to our community in the form of events and mutual-aid initiatives that directly benefit our diverse community, while indirectly improving the safety, security, and quality of life of LGBTQ2S+ individuals in Medicine Hat through education and awareness initiatives.

Title: Lethbridge Pride Fest 2017
Summary:
Pride Fest 2017 ran from June 16-24, 2017 and featured the following events:

June 16, 2017: University of Lethbridge Pride Flag Raising at University of Lethbridge (4401 University Dr. W.) at 10:30 a.m.
June 16, 2017: Ages 14-18 Black Light Youth Dance Boys & Girls Club (1405 8 Ave. N.) at 7:00 p.m. Music by DJ Rabbyt
June 17, 2017: Social Swing Dancing at Eagles Hall (631 13 St. N.) at 8:00 p.m.
June 17, 2017: My Homo Highness: Queer Inspirations at Club Didi (517A 4 Ave. S.) at 9:00 p.m. Didi d'Edada. Stick around after the show and continue the celebration as the night continues with a Panti Raid after party.
June 18, 2017: Church Service at McKillop United Church (2329 15 Ave. S.) at 10:00 a.m. & 11:30 a.m.
June 18, 2017: Jeopardy: Category is... HIV/AIDS at Lethbridge Public Library (810 5 Ave. S.) 1:30 p.m. Hosted by drag queen Molly Dooker
June 18, 2017: Where the Two-Spirit Lives at Lethbridge Public Library (810 5 Ave. S.) at 3:00 p.m. Join us for Lethbridge's first two-spirit recognition panel discussion, as Marshall Vielle explores the nature of Queer culture from a First Nations perspective.
June 18, 2017: Trans March Start: Galt Gardens - End: City Hall. Begins at 6:00 p.m.
June 19, 2017: Pride Flag Raising at City Hall at 6:30 p.m. Flag raisers: Dr. Wesley Govender & a member of the Lethbridge Police Service. Prior to the flag raising, a Blackfoot Elder will lead a smudging ceremony.
June 19, 2017: Queen Scarlet Cinema: Paris is Burning at CASA (230 8 St. S.) at 7:00 p.m.
June 19, 2017: Jeffery Straker Concert at McKillop United Church (2329 15 Ave. S.) at 7:30 p.m.
June 19, 2017: Swing Dancing at Eagles Hall (631 13 St. N.) at 7:30 p.m. Join Swing Bridge Dance Club for a night of swing dancing.
June 20, 2017: Express Yourself at Catwalk Salon & Spa (618 3 Ave. S.) at 6:30 p.m.
June 20, 2017: Teddy Talks: Inclusion & Diverse Gender Norms at UofL SU Ballrooms (4401 University Dr. W.) at 7:00 p.m. Teddy Syrette is a Two-Spirit Gender-Fluid Indigenous Advocate and Artist from the Batchewana First Nation, Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario.
June 20, 2017: Smoke Eaters & Wint at The Owl (411 3 Ave. S.) at 9:00 p.m. Join us as Smoke Eaters and Wint perform and celebrate their identities as LGBTQ+ bands.
June 21, 2017: LGBTQ+ Movie: Two Soft Things, Two Hard Things at Lethbridge Public Library (810 5 Ave. S.) & Kainai Public Library at 7:00 p.m. Please join Fairy Tales Queer Film Festival for a film exploring the small but burgeoning community of LGBT Inuit people living in Nunavut
June 21, 2017: Supermoon & Open Channels at The Owl (411 3 Ave. S.) at 9:00 p.m. Join us as Supermoon and Open Channels perform and celebrate their identities as LGBTQ+ bands.
June 22, 2017: Coming Out Monologues at Lethbridge Public Library (810 5 Ave. S.) at 8:00 p.m.
June 22, 2017: Open Mic at Club Didi (517A 4 Ave. S.) at 9:00 p.m.
June 22, 2017: Gay-mes Night at KAPOW at Kapow Ltd. Comics (320 6 St. S.) at 7:00 p.m.
June 23, 2017: Pride Awards & Chair's Martini Gala at Galt Museum & Archives (502 1 St. S.) at 7:00 p.m.
June 23, 2017: Martini Night After Party at Hudson's Canada's Pub (904 2 Ave. S.) at 11:00 p.m.
June 24, 2017: Lethbridge Pride Parade. Start: Lethbridge City Hall - End: Galt Gardens. Begins at 12PM
June 24, 2017: Pride in the Park at Galt Gardens beginning at 12:30 p.m.
June 24, 2017: Cabinet of Queeriosities IV: Opening Reception at CASA (230 8 St. S.) at 7:00 p.m.
June 24, 2017: 18+ Life in Plastic Pride Dance with Special Guest Trixie Mattel at Multicultural Centre (421 6 Ave. S.) starting 8:00 p.m. Hosted by Cici Diamonds and performances by Molly Dooker and Fendi Ashleen La'Fierce

Title: Lethbridge Pride Fest 10th Anniversary Art Project 2018
Summary: To commemorate the 10th anniversary of Lethbridge Pride celebrations, Lethbridge Pride Fest commissioned a local art project featuring the word "Pride" and a heart, with each letter and the heart being painted in one of the rainbow colours by 6 independent local artists adding queer art to each letter and the heart.

Title: Lethbridge Chosen as One of 50 Canadian Cities for "Standing by our colours" commemoration
Summary: Lethbridge was chosen as one of fifty cities across Canada to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the partial decriminalization of Homosexuality in Canada. There was a commemorative flag raising ceremony held on May 15, 2019 at City Hall at 5:30PM to mark the anniversary. Speakers included: Mayor Chris Spearman, Suzanne Lenon & Wednesday Culley.

Title: Lethbridge Pride Fest 2023
Summary:
Pride Fest 2023 ran from June 18-24, 2023 and featured the following events:

June 18 – 12 p.m.: Trans March at Galt Gardens. Help Lethbridge Pride kick-off Pride Week by joining us for the Trans March! We will start by gathering at the Galt Garden’s park by the stage area prior to 12:00 PM and then march to Lethbridge City Hall.
June 18 – 2 p.m. and 7 p.m.: Drag Me To The Opera with Aida Cupcake at Didi's Playhaus. 12+ event. This event is hosted and organized by Aida Cupcake.
June 19 – 11 a.m.: Pride Flag Raising at the University of Lethbridge. Join the University of Lethbridge and Lethbridge Pride in celebrating Pride Week on Campus as they raise the Pride Flag! We’ll be raising the flag at the Student Union Bus Loop.
June 19 – 6 p.m.: Pride Flag Raising at Lethbridge City Hall. Hosted by Lethbridge College and Lethbridge Pride Fest. Artists/Performers: Tom Littlebear for a Blackfoot Blessing and the Raging Grannies
June 20 – 11 a.m.: Pride Flag Raising at Lethbridge College
June 20 – 5:30 p.m.: LADY GAGA TOGETHER WE RISE Ride with Vanessa spin class at UNITE YQL
June 20 – 5:45 p.m. to 8 p.m.: Queer Film Series – 'Boulevard' at Lethbridge Public Library - Main Branch.
June 22 – 6 p.m. - 8 p.m.: Paint and Sip: Pride Edition with Artist Sarah Peace at Galt Museum & Archives.
June 22 – 6:45 p.m. - 7:45 p.m.: The Book Dragons: Cemetery Boys at Lethbridge Public Library – Crossings Branch.
June 23 – 5:30 p.m.: GET YOUR PRIDE ON Ride spin class with Tricia at UNITE YQL
June 23 – 7 p.m.: Chairs Martini Award Night at Galt Museum & Archives. Headliners: Brandi Jayne, Dayna Hart, Addi Pose and Ashley Northey
June 24 – 8 a.m. to 11 a.m.: Pre-Parade Breakfast at Chef Stella
June 24 – 11 a.m: Pride Parade in Galt Gardens. Starting just behind the Ice Civic Centre, the parade begins at 11:00 AM, we move north on Stafford Drive S, taking a left on 3rd Ave S, and a final right turn onto 5th St. S to finish the parade and begin our day-long celebrations in Galt Gardens!
June 24 – 11:30 a.m. to 5 p.m.: Pride In The Park at Galt Gardens.
June 24 – 10 p.m. to 4 a.m.: 15th Annual Pride Dance at Southern Alberta Ethnic Association. Lethbridge Pride. Headliners: Brandi Jayne, Dayna Hart, P﻿oppy Puffter, M﻿r. Justin Syde, I﻿mogen Rouge, and from RuPaul's Canada Drag Race, Stephanie Prince, S2 + Canada Vs. The World, Juice Boxx, S1 and Kaos, S3. Music by DJ MORRISMORRIS

Title: First Peace River Pride Parade
Summary: Peace River holds its first Pride Parade

Title: Peace River Pride Festival 2013
Summary:
The festivities begin Friday June 14th at 7pm. The McNamera Hotel Bar, located in Peace River (1022 100 Street) will host a meet and greet. This will allow for out of town guests to get a feel for the community and mingle.

Saturday the 15th is a packed day; patrons will be kept busy with a colourful set of events. On Saturday morning, behind Horizon, (9801 100 Street) there will be face painting and a craft setup for poster making. At 12pm the parade will kick off. Patrons can make a float, walk with a group, ride a bike, scooter down, or just sit back and enjoy the show. Attendees are encouraged to wear their hats and lather the SPF; it is important to have fun outdoors, and be sun-safe at the same time. Following the parade, at 1pm the Riverfront Park activities will begin which will include: a BBQ, face painting, music and other entertainment. At 4pm, River City Cinema will have a free screening of the 14A movie Cloudburst. The evening events will commence at 6pm, with a play and dance party at Java Dominion. Java Dominion will offer music entertainment and an open mic session for sharing experiences at Riverfront Park following the parade.

The weekend will draw to a close Sunday morning with an informal breakfast. This allows for attendees to say their goodbyes to their new friends, and draw a great weekend to a close.

Arts & Crafts - Friday June 7 6-8 pm at the NAR Station 9409 100 St. In partnership with the Peace River Museum Archives & Mackenzie Centre join us for the opening of the Dear Friends Photo Exhibit. There will also be button and sign making for pride.Refreshments provided, bring creativity!

Title: Peace River Pride Cancelled due to COVID-19 2020
Summary:
The Peace River Pride Society’s board announced on April 16 they have made the “heart-wrenching decision” to postpone the 2020 Pride Parade and events.

It would have been Peace River Pride’s 10th anniversary year. It started as a small march on the sidewalk in 2010 in Peace River and eventually grew to a full parade and other events.

Title: Peace River Pride Week Declared 2020
Summary:
Following a request from the Peace River Pride Society, LGBTQ2+ Pride Week has been officially proclaimed in the Town of Peace River from May 29 – June 5, 2020. The Pride Flag has also been raised at the community flagpole located in the downtown roundabout for the week. Flag walk – Saturday, May 30

Games Night – Monday, June 1 @ 7 pm

Wellness Wednesday Webinar – Wednesday, June 3 @ 7 pm

Movie Night – Friday, June 5 @ 7:30 pm

Title: Peace River Pride in a Box 2021

Title: Peace River Pride Week Declared 2021
Summary: This morning Deputy Mayor Elaine Manzer attended the raising of the LGBTQ2S+ Pride Flag along with members from the Peace River Pride Society. The flag will fly until June 18 as part of the Peace River’s LGBTQ2S+ Pride Week, which has been officially proclaimed in Peace River.

Title: Peace River Pride Society did not hold a Pride Parade 2022
Summary: With the changing status of Covid, the board made a decision early in the year that we would not hold a parade. we did hear from several members that the parade was something that people looked forward to each year and that people understood why the parade was not happening in 2022. as parades take a lot of organizing I have lots of details. Once Covid restrictions changed we didn’t have enough time to plan a parade, and we were able to hold a community event. This event was very well attended and successful. We were able to partner with Tapped Out Gaming and hold an evening of karaoke and nachos; Saturday was day of bowling and other activities for the community.

Title: Jasper Pride Event 2009
Summary: An article from 2011 notes: "Last year’s premiere event was attended by about 40 people along with friends and supporters. There was a plethora of activities and a night of dance and drink."

Title: Jasper Pride Weekend 2010
Summary:
This year Pride Jasper runs from February 11th to 13th. Mountain Park Lodges and Chateau Jasper is the host hotel and they are featuring guest rooms for $79.00+tax per night (based on single/double occupancy). You are welcome to book at another hotel if you prefer, but if you would like to stay at the Chateau Jasper you can give them a call at 1-888-8JASPER to book your room.

There will be a mixer on the Friday night that comes complimentary with the Pride Package. It will be held in the Skyline Room, Lobstick Lodge right beside Chateau Jasper. There will be a cash bar, reception compliments and live music by local performer Sam Heine. There will also be a silent auction benefitting OUT Jasper.

On Saturday OUT Jasper and HIV West Yellowhead will be hosting a themed party at the Jasper Activity Centre. The cost is a small fee of $10.00 and again, all of the proceeds will go towards future events for OUT Jasper that include activities and peer support. There will be a performance by Rae Spoon, a drag show and dance with DJ Feen.

The two days worth of events include ski days. Marmot Basin will be featuring an Après Ski in the Lower Chalet at 3:00pm on Saturday afternoon.

Title: Jasper Pride Weekend 2012

Title: Central Alberta Pride in the Park Program 2017
Summary:
Pride in the Park was held on August 13, 2017 at Bower Ponds from 11:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m.


The lineup of speeches and performances was as follows:


11:00 a.m. - Live music begins with Ryan Marchant. Beer gardens and activities open for the day

12:00 p.m. - Formal program, including Mayor's Proclamation by Deputy Mayor Ken Johnston 

12:20 p.m. - Performance by local drag queen Kelli Eletrix 

12:25 p.m. - Live music resumes with Trombone Choir 

12:35 p.m. - Michelle Laine Music 

1:15 p.m. Randi Boulton Music 

2:00 p.m. - Bradley Abel 

2:45 p.m. - The KlamDaggers 

3:35 p.m. - Performance by local drag queen Sparkle P Emotion 

4:00 p.m. - Bradley Abel 

5:00 p.m. - 89 Red Deer's other band! 

6:00 p.m. - Event concludes (but feel free to stay and enjoy the park as long as you like)

August 12: TD presents Pride in the Park at Bower Ponds from 11:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m. We'll kick off the day with a Worship in the Park followed by a Mayor's Proclamation before a day filled with live music, local vendors, food trucks and a bouncy castle. Title: Ponoka Pride and Community GSA Founded
Summary: Ponoka Pride and Community GSA was founded in 2021

Title: First Ponoka Pride Celebration Hosted by Ponoka Pride and Community GSA
Summary: Ponoka Pride and Community GSA held its first Pride celebration on June 28, 2021. The celebration kicked off with the raising of the Pride flag at the Town of Ponoka Environmental Services Building (the old Fire Hall). There was a performance by local recording artist Shalaine Stebner, popcorn and story time sponsored by the Ponoka Jubilee Library. Attendees were invited to draw with sidewalk chalk and there were Pride button giveaways.

Title: First Ponoka Pride Flag Rising Ceremony by Ponoka Pride and Community GSA
Summary: An official Pride flag raising ceremony was held at the Town of Ponoka Environmental Services Building (the old Fire Hall) on Monday, June 28, 2021. The ceremony began with a Treaty 6 land acknowledgement. The Town of Ponoka also projected the Pride flag colours onto the Ponoka Civic Building via a light display that could be viewed after sunset. The Pride flag was flown from June 28, 2021 to July 20, 2021

Title: Municipal Government Involvement in Ponoka Pride 2021
Summary: Town of Ponoka Councillors Teri Underhill and Clayton Nelson attended the Pride flag raising ceremony

Title: Ponoka Pride Performer 2021
Summary: Local recording artist Shalaine Stebner performed at the Pride flag raising ceremony

Title: Ponoka Pride and Community GSA withdraw parade float from 2022 Ponoka Stampede Parade
Summary: Ponoka Pride and Community GSA were planning to participate in the Ponoka Stampede Parade in 2022, but withdrew their parade float from participation as they did not have enough volunteers and did not feel safe enough to participate

Title: The LGBTQ+ Society of Lloydminster Founded
Summary: The LGBTQ+ Society of Lloydminster was founded in April 2015 by Board President, Tiffani Wiesner.

Title: First Lloydminster Pride Week
Summary: Lloydminster’s first ever Pride Week was proclaimed with a rainbow flag-raising ceremony at city hall.

Title: LGBTQ+ Society of Lloydminster Facebook Page Created
Summary: Page name changed to “LGBTQ+ Society of Lloydminster – Events” May 24, 2018

Title: First Lloydminster Pride in the Park
Summary: Lloydminster Pride will wrap up Pride week with their first ever public event. The LGBTQ+ Society of Lloydminster has events all month long including Pride Week which kicks off June 25th to 30th. To put a cap on the celebration during the month, the Society is putting together their first ever public event “Pride in the Park” on June 30th at Weaver Park.

Title: Lloydminster Pride Week 2019
Summary: The whole week aims at bringing the local community of gender and sexual minorities a bit closer to its neighbours. Kale Dudley is a member of the planning committee behind Pride Week and believes it’s important to create a sense of community

Title: Lloydminster Pride 2020
Summary: The Society, like many other non-profits, is facing challenges due to COVID-19. They have begun planning several events, including online drag shows, learning tutorials and art events, among other events online, working around the pandemic.

Title: Lloydminster Drag Queen Bingo and Virtual Dance 2020
Summary: Join us for Virtual Drag Queen Bingo, hosted by Craig Peterson of Sound Wave Entertainment, your favourite local queens, and special guests! We will be running this event through Zoom on Friday, June 26th starting at 7:00 p.m. Following the Bingo, we will continue the evening with a Virtual Dance Party! Please note, that this is an 18+ event.

Title: Lloydminster Pride Week Scavenger Hunt 2020
Summary: First Pride Week scavenger hunt. There are 17 locations around Lloydminster that have dawned our Rainbow Heart Decal to help show their Pride and help us celebrate ours! Participants followed clues posted on Facebook to find the hearts, took photos of them, and send them via email to be entered to win a prize.

Title: Lloydminster Pride Week LGBTQ Story Time 2020
Summary: Virtual series of events. Each day of Pride Week, a variety of hosts post readings of our favorite LGBTQ Story Books!

Title: Lloydminster Pride Walk 2020
Summary:
Very first PRIDE WALK at Bud Miller Park
Meeting in the parking lot of the Picnic Area, and then heading out for our walk in staggered groups of 15 people or less at a time.
We encourage all participants to show off your PRIDE by dressing up, carrying signs, flags, noise makers, etc.
We will be respecting COVID safety measures during this event, and strongly encourage all participants to wear a mask.

Title: Hybrid Lloydminster Pride 2021
Summary: Lloyd Pride hosted in a hybrid format, with online events (e.g. Facebook, Zoom) and modified in-person events including outdoor and independent participation activities (e.g. rock hunt). The march was held outdoors and with COVID-19 measures.

Title: Lloydminster Pride Walk 2021
Summary:
The LGBTQ+ Society of Lloydminster, with event sponsorship from Synergy Credit Union, are proud to invite you to join us for our second PRIDE WALK to kick off Lloyd Pride 2021!
Start at Cenovus Energy (formerly Husky Oil Operations Ltd.) parking lot (4335 44 St). Our walking route will take us along Hwy 16 to Synergy Credit Union, where this year's official Lloyd Flag Raising will be held, and back again to Cenovus Energy. Approx. 4km
Due to provincial safety regulations, we will require participants to sign their group or "Team" up for a specific time slot this year. Teams can include up to 10 individuals, and we ask groups to consist of people within the same household “bubble”.
19 groups attended

Title: Lloydminster Virtual Flag Raising and Pride Week Kick-Off 2021
Summary: Join us on Facebook LIVE @lgbtqlloyd as we kick off Lloyd Pride 2021 with an online Flag Raising at Synergy Credit Union, our official Sponsors for the Lloyd Pride Walk, 2021!

Title: Lloydminster Drive-in Drag Show 2021
Summary:
Slay the Night YLL Ltd. and the LGBTQ+ Society of Lloydminster are honoured to host the Lloydminster stop of the YXE Drag Collective's DRAG ME ACROSS SASKATCHEWAN Drive-In Drag Show tour
All-ages show at 7pm
16+ show at 9pm
Local Drag Performers will be joining Monarchs from the YXE Drag Collective in TWO live and in-person Drive-In drag shows

Title: Lloydminster Pride Walk 2022
Summary: The difference this year, is we all get to walk TOGETHER! That's right - we will not be walking in "shifts" this year. With that in mind, we are highly encouraging "teams" to come out as a group and show their pride. Businesses, companies, organizations, groups, clubs, friends... come wave your flags and blaze your colours!

Participate in, or gently witness, activities involving sharing stories, exploring connection and safe touch, and co-creating a sculpture, or just find a nice spot to hang. Enjoy ambient visuals, and music by Applecat - with a mellow vibe in the early evening, building to danceable tunes around 9 pm.

Title: Salt Spring Opioid Overdose Recovery Training 2018
Summary:
Overdose recovery training is invaluable for our community - and is offered for free, in a training session that arms you with the knowledge, skills, and kit to confidently administer the treatment.
Tuesday Aug. 27 at 10:30am, behind Lady Minto hospital in the portable (or outside on the picnic tables if good weather)
-or-
Wednesday Aug. 28 at 2:00pm, behind Lady Minto hospital in the Annex (or outside on the picnic tables if good weather)
You will leave with an overdose recovery kit that contains 3 doses of Naloxone (the name of the drug).

Title: First Salt Spring Island Pride Festival
Summary: Welcome to the Q'itchen Table - Opening Ceremony is 3:00 Friday with special and honoured guests. / Daily Open Mics - Friday 7-9pm, Saturday 3-5pm, Sunday 7-9pm. / Boa Karaoke - Friday and Sunday 8:30pm / Parade - Saturday 11:30am, Starting on Rainbow Rd, ending at the Salt Spring Public Library/ Dance - Saturday 7-11pm. Featuring DJ Michael Burkett and Goodnight Sunrise Band / The is a State of Emergency - Sunday at 11:00am. Title: Elk Valley Pride Festival 2022
Summary: The Elk Valley Pride Festival 2022 took place. On September 21st, the following events occurred: Bike decorating at the Arts Station and Rainbow Reels Queering in the Interior at Senior Centre. On the 22nd, there was The Festival Opening Gathering at City Hall, Opening Remarks and Flag Raising, Ride with Pride Bike Parade, Rainbow Connections with the Pub Pride Picnic, and Spirits & Songs. On the 23rd, the events included Drag Storytime at Fernie Heritage Library, Kootenay Queer Robert Verigin at Seniors Centre, Cooking with Queens for Teens at Senior Centre, Drag Paint & Sip at the Arts Station, and Never Nuff Drag Show at the Pub. On September 24th, there was the Wheelie Out Skate Jam, Spectrum Queer Arts Day at City Hall, and Rainbow Reads with Smokii Sumac at Fernie Heritage Library. On Sep 25th, there were events like Pride Pub Parade at Railyard Dog Park, Interfaith Service at Christ Church Anglican, Nuff Sisters Sunday Sip Brunch at Seniors Centre, and Queers on Gears Meet at Aquatic Centre.

Title: Phase 2 of the Elk Valley Capacity Project
Summary: In February 2022, the second phase of the Elk Valley Capacity Project was initiated, marking an important milestone in the ongoing efforts to enhance inclusivity and equity within the community. As part of this phase, the project saw the establishment of a Columbia Basin 2SLGBTQ+ Network, which is a significant step forward in fostering connections and collaboration within the region to further support the 2SLGBTQ+ community's needs and aspirations. This development underscores the continued commitment of the Fernie Pride Society to create a more inclusive and supportive environment in the Elk Valley and the broader Columbia Basin area.

Title: Fernie Pride Society Facebook Debut
Summary: The Fernie Pride Society creates its Facebook account

Title: Fernie Pride Society Foundation
Summary: The Fernie Pride Society was formally incorporated with six board members on December 13, 2016. Their mission is to support and connect the 2SLGBTQ+ community in the Elk Valley. Following their incorporation, focus groups were held at a coffee shop called the Valley Social, and from these discussions, a monthly program called Beers & Queers (now known as Rainbow Connections) emerged.

Title: Fernie Pride Society Logo Release
Summary: The logo was released

Title: Elk Valley Pride Festival 2017
Summary: The Elk Valley Pride Festival featured a variety of events, starting with a Literary Evening on October 11th, followed by a captivating performance called "Miss Ellen Q and The Pumas" on October 12th. On October 13th, the community came together for Beers and Queers, and laughter filled the air at a Comedy Event on October 14th. Wrapping up the festivities, October 15th offered a Park Place Brunch and a nature-themed Fairy Creek Hike, providing a diverse range of activities for festival attendees to enjoy.

On October 10th, an event called "Author Evening with Angi Abdou" was celebrated. On October 11th, another encounter with the author Rae Spoon took place at the Fernie Arts Station. On October 12th, Drag Queen Story Time occurred. On October 13th, a Drag-stravaganza event happened. Finally, on October 14th, a Big Gay Brunch took place.

Title: Fernie Pride Society Board Member Incorporation 2020
Summary: The organization warmly welcomes Easton to the board of the Fernie Pride Society! Easton is taking on the role of Youth Member, a newly created position within the organization.

Title: Elk Valley Pride Festival 2020
Summary: The Elk Valley Pride Festival 2020 took place. On September 21st, a Drag Bingo occurred. On September 23rd, an event called "Sewing 101" took place. On September 24th, the following events took place: Art on the Deck at Arts Station, Art History with Jackie, Festival Opening Ceremony and Flag Raising, Pride Bike Parade, Pride City Hall Social, and Beers and Queers at the Royal. On September 25th, the following events occurred: Drag Story and Craft Time, Rainbow Foundation of Hope Presentation, Cooking with Queens, and Reel out Drive-in Movie at Fernie Alpine Resort. On September 26th, the following events took place: Rainbow Connections Scavenger Hunt, OUTstanding on the Table Youth Brunch, Contemporary Fernie Queer History Walk, Interfaith Pride Worship Service, and Rainbow Reads. On September 27th, there were events like Drag Trivia Brunch and the Puppy Pride Parade and Social at Rallyard Dog Park.

Title: Fernie Pride Society Board of Directors
Summary: The board members include Kevin Allen as President, Melissa Creelman serving as Vice-President, Jennifer Asselin fulfilling the role of Secretary/Treasurer, and Anie Hepher, Andrea Brennan, Mary Cosman, Sarah Laverick, and Dan Whillans as Directors. Together, they work collaboratively to advance the society's initiatives and support the 2SLGBTQ+ community in the Elk Valley.

Title: Phase 1 of the Elk Valley Capacity Project
Summary: The Fernie Pride Society has initiated the first phase of the Elk Valley Capacity Project, a significant undertaking aimed at enhancing 2SLGBTQ+ inclusivity and equity in the community. To achieve this, the society is actively engaging with residents, visitors, and community stakeholders to gain a comprehensive understanding of the 2SLGBTQ+ community's needs and identify local barriers to achieving complete social, cultural, and economic inclusion. As the project progresses, Fernie Pride aims to gather essential insights that will inform the development of targeted community interventions. Subsequently, the society intends to secure the necessary funding and resources to implement these interventions effectively. Notably, they have already produced valuable resources, including a 2SLGBTQ+ Workplace Inclusion Guide, an Ally Toolkit, established partnerships with other organizations, and published two reports titled "Elk Valley Diversity and Inclusion: Needs Assessment Results July 2021" and "Strengthening Community Capacity for Inclusion in BC's Elk Valley August 2021." These endeavors mark significant steps toward fostering a more inclusive and equitable Elk Valley.

Title: Elk Valley Pride Festival 2021
Summary: The Elk Valley Pride Festival 2021 took place. On September 23rd, the following events occurred: Queer 101 for Parents and Caregivers, Flag Raising and Festival Opening, Ride with Pride Bike Parade, Rainbow Connections Pub Picnic, and Spirits and Songs at Fernie Distillers. On September 24th, there were events like Drag Story + Craft Time, Men’s Health Initiative Presentation, Creating Inclusive Spaces Presentation, Cooking with Queens, and Rainbow Reads. On September 25th, the events included Queer and Trans History of BC, Spectrum Arts Festival, Stage to Screen with Pam Rocker, and Drag Bingo. Finally, on September 26th, there were activities such as the Pup Parade and Coffee Social, Interfaith Service, Drag Brunch, and Elk Valley Inclusion and Diversity Project Presentation.

Title: Fernie Pride Society Twitter/X Debut
Summary: The Fernie Pride Society creates its Twitter account

Title: First Queer Out Here Conference
Summary: The inaugural Queer Out Here conference in February 2023 was a resounding success, bringing together and educating over 100 2SLGBTQ+ individuals and allies hailing from 19 different communities. This significant event not only facilitated connections but also provided valuable insights and knowledge-sharing opportunities, further strengthening the bonds within the 2SLGBTQ+ community and its allies across diverse regions.

Title: Elk Valley Pride Festival 2023
Summary: The Elk Valley Pride Festival 2023 took place. On Wednesday, September 20th, there was a Bike Decorating event and a Movie Screening at the Arts Station. On Thursday, September 21st, the Flag Raising event and the Pride Ride Bike Parade occurred at City Hall. Later in the day, a Pub Pride Picnic took place, along with a Spirits and Songs event at Fernie Distillers. On Friday, September 22nd, the following events took place: Pride Stride with Hike Fernie, Drag Story & Craft Time, Queer History Lunch & Learn, All Bodies Swim, Teen Skateboard Deck Painting, Queer Beer Social, Rainbow Reads, and Drag Me Downton. On Saturday, September 23rd, there was an event called Queers on Gears Ride Theory Bike Ride and the Spectrum Queer Arts Day. Finally, on Sunday, September 24th, an Interfaith Service took place, followed by a Drag Brunch.

Title: Moose Jaw Pride Week 2013
Summary: On June 28, 2013, Moose Jaw Pride Day took place at the Mae Wilson Theater. Commencing at 3 PM, a symbolic Rainbow Flag Raising ceremony occurred, marking an important moment of unity and inclusivity. Following this, at 6:30 PM and 8:30 PM, Forward Family Film Night unfolded, offering an evening of cinematic enjoyment for all attendees.

Title: Moose Jaw Pride Non-Profit Incorporation

Title: Moose Jaw Pride Flag Raising Event 2014
Summary: The 2014 Pride Flag raising event took place.

Title: Moose Jaw Pride Queen's Message 2014
Summary: The Lieutenant Governor of the Province of Saskatchewan, Hon. Vaughn Solomon Schofield, extended her greetings on behalf of H.M. Queen Elizabeth II to everyone gathered for the Pride Flag Raising Ceremony in Moose Jaw.

Title: Moose Jaw Pride Week 2014
Summary: The 2014 Moose Jaw Pride events unfolded as follows: On May 14, a Guest lecture was held at the Moose Jaw Museum & Art Gallery. The following day, a diversity discussion event took place. On Friday, May 16, the Performer's Cafe, Pride Edition, took center stage. Saturday, May 17, commenced with the Pride Flag Raising Ceremony, followed by a day filled with activities until midnight. MLA for Regina Coronation, Mark Docherty, and the Mayor of Moose Jaw participated in the festivities. Activities continued on May 18 and concluded on May 19 with a Relaxing Rainbow Spa Day.

Title: Moose Jaw Pride Week 2015
Summary: The 2015 Moose Jaw Pride Week unfolded from May 24 to May 30. Events commenced on May 24 with a celebration at St. Andrew's United Church and an activity at Crescent Park Bandshell. Throughout the week, activities persisted until May 30, when major events took place, including the Flag Raising Ceremony, a Community Fair, and an After Party.

Title: Moose Jaw Pride Week 2016
Summary: The 2016 Moose Jaw Pride Week spanned from May 29 to June 4. On May 29, two distinct events occurred at St. Andrew's United Church and Crescent Park Amphitheater. Throughout the week, a variety of events unfolded, including film screenings, game nights, photo shoots, trivia contests, and performances. The culmination of the week occurred on June 4 with the Moose Jaw Pride Parade, featuring activities like the Pride Flag Raising ceremony, parties, and more.

Title: Moose Jaw Pride Instagram Debut
Summary: The Moose Jaw Pride made its debut on Instagram.

Title: Moose Jaw Pride Youth Leadership Camp 2016
Summary: The 2016 Youth Leadership Camp was held, inviting LGBTQ+ Youth Allies in Grades 7-12 to participate for free. The camp aimed to provide education on sexual health and mental health.

Title: Moose Jaw Pride Week 2017
Summary: The 2017 Moose Jaw Pride Week occurred with various events. On May 1st, flag raising events marked the beginning. Activities persisted throughout the week, including lunches, performer cafes, trivia nights, dances, and art shows. The highlight came on May 6 with the Parade, followed by community fairs and an after-party. The week concluded on May 7th with a Faith service.

Title: Moose Jaw Pride Flag Raising Event 2018
Summary: The Transgender Pride flag was raised at Peacock Collegiate.

Title: Moose Jaw Pride Week 2018
Summary: The 2018 Moose Jaw Pride Week unfolded with a series of events. On July 22, festivities began with a smudging ceremony, followed by a Pride flag raising and a faith service at the Crescent Park Amphitheatre. Throughout the weekdays, various activities were organized, including lunches, painting sessions, trivia nights, and art shows. The highlight occurred on July 28 with the Parade, accompanied by live entertainment music and an after-party.

Title: Moose Jaw Pride Week 2019
Summary: The 2019 Moose Jaw Pride unfolded with a series of events. The Flag Raising ceremony kicked off on May 26, followed by various activities including painting sessions, readings, trivia nights, and a performer's night throughout the week. On June 1st, the Parade took center stage, followed by live entertainment and an after-party to continue the celebration.

Title: Moose Jaw Pride Week 2021
Summary: The 2021 Moose Jaw Pride Week was predominantly held virtually. The week commenced with the flag raising ceremony in Crescent Park on May 23. On May 24, a social activity was hosted over Zoom, followed by two discussion panels scheduled for May 25 and 26. The annual trivia night took place on May 28, and the Pride Parade filled the streets on May 29.

Title: Moose Jaw Pride Statement regarding possible criminal activities of former volunteer 2021
Summary: The organization issued a statement regarding a criminal incident involving a former volunteer, expressing their commitment to reviewing their safety policies thoroughly.

Title: Moose Jaw Pride Week 2022
Summary: The 2022 Moose Jaw Pride was celebrated with various activities starting from May 22 onwards, including live music performances and nature events. The Flag Raising ceremony took place on May 27, and the week concluded with a Faith Service on May 28.

Title: Moose Jaw Pride Removal of the Executive Director 2022
Summary: The Board of Directors has announced that the Executive Director is no longer part of the organization.

Title: Moose Jaw Pride Annual General Meeting 2022
Summary: An Annual General Meeting was held, during which it was resolved to dissolve the organization due to financial liabilities.

Title: Moose Jaw Pride Week 2023
Summary: The 2023 Moose Jaw Pride ran from May 25 to June 3 with a dynamic lineup. It kicked off with the Performers Cafe on May 25, followed by community dinners, affirming church services, and HIV self-testing sessions. The week also featured sign-making events, suicide prevention training, and a poignant Coming Out Campfire. The celebration culminated on June 3 with a vibrant parade and a serene picnic accompanied by live performances at Crescent Park.
